title: Nothing to be scared about
text:
FNQ has a very ghostly history by: What are these? THAT’S THE SPIRIT: Junior ghost Neti Raea, 11, dresses up in preparation for the coming Halloween and looks forward to watching her Casper DVD. PICTURE: JUSTIN BRIERTY Source: News Corp Australia 
CASPER might be the original friendly ghost, but the Far North is said to have a benevolent spirit of its own. 
Paronella Park marketing and promotion manager Luke Evans said there were a host of ghostly stories surrounding the attraction, but the most common was that the castle’s founder, Jose Paronella, continued to watch over his creation. 
A self-confessed sceptic, Mr Evans said visitors often reported feeling Mr Paro­nella’s “presence” during night tours. 
“It’s often spoken about as a positive presence,” he said. 
Mr Evans said that during past cyclones, wind had pushed large trees over in such a way that they had fallen without doing any damage to the buildings. 
“People talk about Jose looking over the park and protecting it,” he said. 
If a real-life encounter with Mr Paronella isn’t quite your thing, you can relive all the ghostly goodness of the 1995 family action comedy Casper , available for $2.50 from participating newsagents, Coles, Woolworths and IGA supermarkets with a token inside Monday’s The Cairns Post. 
It comes after yesterday’s Stuart Little token in The Weekend Post , and The Lorax token included in today’s The Sunday Mail . 
There are 14 DVDs to collect as part of the Ultimate Family Movie Collection.
